Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Ozone-driven processes for mature urban landfill leachate treatment: Organic matter degradation, biodegradability enhancement and treatment costs for different reactors configuration.

AbstractText: In this work, the application of ozone-driven processes for the treatment of mature landfill leachate was investigated by testing different system setups. As a first approach, ozonation (O<sub>3</sub>-only) was tested, using a porous ceramic diffuser combined with a bubble column (BC), and the best operational conditions were established for leachate treatment (initial pH = 9.0; inlet ozone dose = 18 mg O<sub>3</sub>/min). Then, a novel photoreactor (FluHelik) was coupled in series with the bubble column, using a diffuser or a Venturi to inject ozone into the fluid stream. The FluHelik/BC-Venturi setup led to the highest efficiency, treating 50% more leachate than BC-alone using the same ozone dose and reaction time (3 h). Following, the oxidation ability of ozone combined with H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> and/or UVC for leachate treatment was assessed. The highest synergistic effect was obtained for the O<sub>3</sub>/UVC process, with pseudo-first-order rate constant for DOC and COD removal, 2.0 and 1.4 times higher than for the O<sub>3</sub>-only, respectively. Ozone-driven processes considerably enhanced the leachate biodegradability from 17% to 79% (O<sub>3</sub>/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>), 81% (O<sub>3</sub>-only), 85% (O<sub>3</sub>/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>/UVC) and 91% (O<sub>3</sub>/UVC), after a 3 h reaction period. With FluHelik/BC-Venturi system, the O<sub>3</sub>/UVC process stands out as the most efficient and cost-effective (6.0 €/m<sup>3</sup>), ensuring an effluent that meets discharge legal limit for COD (150 mg/L) after further biological oxidation.
